T1021.002::[Brute Ratel C4] has the ability to use SMB to pivot in compromised networks.
T1021.006::[Brute Ratel C4] can use WinRM for pivoting.
T1027.007::[Brute Ratel C4] can call and dynamically resolve hashed APIs.
T1036.005::[Brute Ratel C4] has used a payload file named OneDrive.update to appear benign.
T1036.008::[Brute Ratel C4] has used Microsoft Word icons to hide malicious LNK files.
T1059.003::[Brute Ratel C4] can use cmd.exe for execution.
T1069.002::[Brute Ratel C4] can use `net group` for discovery on targeted domains.
T1071.001::[Brute Ratel C4] can use HTTPS and HTTPS for C2 communication.
T1071.004::[Brute Ratel C4] can use DNS over HTTPS for C2.
T1087.002::[Brute Ratel C4] can use LDAP queries, `net group "Domain Admins" /domain` and `net user /domain` for discovery.
T1204.002::[Brute Ratel C4] has gained execution through users opening malicious documents.
T1497.003::[Brute Ratel C4] can call `NtDelayExecution` to pause execution.
T1518.001::[Brute Ratel C4] can detect EDR userland hooks.
T1558.003::[Brute Ratel C4] can decode Kerberos 5 tickets and convert it to hashcat format for subsequent cracking.
T1562.006::[Brute Ratel C4] has the ability to hide memory artifacts and to patch Event Tracing for Windows (ETW) and the Anti Malware Scan Interface (AMSI).
T1569.002::[Brute Ratel C4] can create Windows system services for execution.
T1574.001::[Brute Ratel C4] has used search order hijacking to load a malicious payload DLL as a dependency to a benign application packaged in the same ISO.

T1574.002::[Brute Ratel C4] has loaded a malicious DLL by spoofing the name of the legitimate Version.DLL  and placing it in the same folder as the digitally-signed Microsoft binary OneDriveUpdater.exe.
